EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Wildwood ,Florida Wastewater Treatment Plant

Background 
The City of Wildwood owns and operates a 2.25 MGD wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) serving approximately 2,000 customers and a service area population of 5,000 people.  

The Wildwood WWTP uses chlorine as a disinfection agent for effluent being discharged to land application systems.  The Wildwood WWTP stores as much as 8,000 lbs of chlorine gas in one-ton cylinders The City of Wildwood developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the chlorine chemical storage and feed facilities in June 1999, in accordance with 40 CFR 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119 (OSHA Process Safety Management Standards). The EPA Chemical Accident Protection rule (40CFR68) applies to any process that involves more than 2,500 pounds of chlorine (gas). The OSHA Process Safety Management standard (29CFR1910.119) applies to any process that involves more than 1,500 pounds of chlorine. The City¿s RMP was submitted to EPA using the agency¿s RMP Submit program.

A compliance audit of the Wildwood WWTP RMP was conducted on June 11, 2004, in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.79.  The audit concluded that the Wildwood WWTP operations are in general compliance with the RMP prepared in June 1999.  

There have been no incidences or chemical release reported in the last five (5) years.

RMP Summary

The Wildwood WWTP RMP is organized as follows:

Section 1 ¿ Emergency Response Plan

This section documents the procedures to be followed to control process upsets and chemical leaks.  The ERP provides procedures to be followed by wastewater personnel for handling minor incidental chlorine releases.

For major chemical releases, the ERP calls for the Wildwood  HAZMAT team (division of the City fire department) to be the first responders.  After notifying the HAZMAT team of a major release occurrence, WWTP personnel are to evacuate the area and allow HAZMAT personnel to take the appropriate emergency response and public notification a

ctions.




Section 2 ¿ Management Plan / Employee participation plan

This section describes the management elements of the RMP, including definition of personnel roles and responsibilities, employee involvement in various elements of the RMP including process safety information. Process hazard analysis, prestart up safety reviews, Management of Change procedures and forms, incident investigation procedures, inspections and compliance audit requirements, training, including updates and development of continuing improvements used by the City.



Section 4 ¿ Hazard Assessment: Offsite Consequence Analysis/ Five-year Accident History

The potential impacts of possible future chlorine release were analyzed in accord with the guidance that USEPA set in its Risk Management Program Guidance for POTWs.  The assessment determines the distance at which the plume would dilute to a concentration at which people would suffer no serious permanent harm, but would voluntarily go to the hospital for evaluation.  For the worst case scenario, it is assumed that a ton container will completely empty in ten minutes.  Although highly unlikely, this is the worst possible case for the plant.  In the worst possible case, the EPA table yields a ¿distance to toxic endpoint¿ of the 3.0 miles for the type of landscape (rural) in which the plant is located.  Within the 3.0-mile radius of the plant, there are schools, a hospital, recreation areas, commercial/office sites, and residences.  An estimated 4,000 people live within a 3.0-mile radius of the plant, based on population projections using 2000 Census data.  

An alternative worst-case scenario was also analyzed using more typical release rates, temperature, wind speed, and atmospheric stability. This results in a chlorine plume with an end point of 0.1 miles for the type of landscape (rural ) in which plant is located.

There has been no accidental release of a regulated substance (chlorine) where exposure to the substance or its reaction

products led to death, injury over the last five years.

Section 5 ¿ Process Safety Information

This section provides a thorough presentation of the physical properties, chemistry and hazards associated with chlorine, and descriptions of the chemical storage and feed process technology, and equipment.  Applicable requirements for design code compliance, and safety systems are also provided.

Section 6 ¿ Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for Chlorination System

This section provides a thorough description of the processes, specifications and operating procedures for the chlorine chemical systems.  The SOPs are developed in a ¿step-by-step¿ format.  The SOPs included in the RMP document address, inspection, temporary operation, emergency procedures, trouble-shooting, cylinder deliveries, system maintenance, safe work practices for handling chlorine, and working in and around chlorine facilities.

Section 7 ¿ Employee Training

This section provides that the City¿s employee involved in operating a process shall be trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures.. The city of Wildwood has developed and conducted regular, structured training for its employees emphasizing on the specific safety, health hazards and emergency operations. Training record certificates documenting the training conducted and employees receiving the subject training are also included in this section.

Section 8 ¿ Mechanical Integrity

Section 9 ¿ Management of Change/ Pre-start up review

Sections 8 and 9 describe written procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of process equipment, to manage changes to process chemicals technology and changes to stationary sources that affect a covered process. It also includes a pre-start up safety review form stating the requirements to be met prior to the introduction of regulated substances to a process.


Section 10 ¿ Process Hazard Analysis 

The Utilities Division Staff using the ¿checklist¿ methodology conducted hazard an

alyses for the chlorination systems.  The PHA developed in June 1999, as a part of the City¿s original RMP submittal was reviewed in June 2004, as part of the RMP re-submittal and found to be adequate. This section includes the exhibits detailing the general condition, operation and maintenance for any WWTP, checklists for chorine usage, storage and transportation.
